assignments.name: Assignment 4
assignments.description:
Heap Sort on Arrays

In this assignment, you will implement the Heap Sort  in C++ using an array of numbers. You will work with a heap to sort the array in ascending order. The task is to build a heap and then use it to sort an array by repeatedly deleting the minimum element.

Steps:

  1. Build the Heap:
    • Starting from the array index 0, build the heap by inserting one element by one element and up-heapifying as you build the Heap array.
    • Remember which index the Left Child and Right Child are inserted for every Node.
  2. Remove the Minimum:
    • Replace the root (minimum element) with the last element of the heap.
    • Reduce the heap size by one and down-heapify.
    • Repeat this process until the heap size is reduced to one.

Task:

You are required to:

  1. Implement the Heapify function that builds the node from the array in the main function
  2. Implement the Heap Sort function that sorts the array. This function calls the Heapify function to build the heap first. 
  3. Heap sort Function will also have the down heap function written into it.
  4. Test your heap sort implementation with an example in the provided main function.
  5. Do not change any of the give code.

Function Descriptions:

  • void heapify(int arr[], int n):

    • This function takes two parameters:
      • arr[]: the array representing the heap.
      • n: the size of the heap.
    • The function builds the heap and is called from the heapSort() function.

  • void heapSort(int arr[], int n):

    • This function takes two parameters:
      • arr[]: the array to be sorted.
      • n: the size of the array.
    • The function first builds a heap and then sorts the array by repeatedly removing the minimum element.

Testing:

  • Your main function will test the heap sort implementation on the array arr[] = {12, 11, 13, 5, 6, 7}. After sorting, the array should be printed in ascending order. 
  • DO NOT CHANGE THIS FUNCTION

Submission:

  • Implement the heapify and heapSort functions.
  • Ensure that your program compiles and runs successfully.
  • Test your program with different input arrays.
  • Submit your code file (.cpp file) by the due date.
#include <iostream>
using namespace std;


void heapify(int arr[], int n) {
    // Your code here
    // Build the heap
}

// Main function to perform heap sort on the array
void heapSort(int arr[], int n) {
    // Step 1: Build a min-heap
 
        heapify(arr, n) 
  

    // Step 2: Extract elements from the heap one by one
   
 // Step 3: Down Heapify
      
    }
}

// Function to print the array
void printArray(int arr[], int n) {
    for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        cout << arr[i] << " ";
    }
    cout << endl;
}

int main() {
    // Test array
    int arr[] = {12, 11, 13, 5, 6, 7};
    int n = sizeof(arr) / sizeof(arr[0]);

    cout << "Original array:\n";
    printArray(arr, n);

    // Call the heapSort function
    heapSort(arr, n);

    cout << "Sorted array:\n";
    printArray(arr, n);

    return 0;
}

assignments.name: Assignment 5
assignments.description:
Submission:
1. Only submit a typed homework, not a written assignment.
2. The homework must be submitted as a PDF
3. All diagrams must be digital. Use an app, do not hand draw on the ipad.
(3+ 3  Points) Suppose there is a Binary Min-Heap with exactly 5 nodes, containing items with priorities 6, 10,
1, 8, 5
a. Show every possible binary min-heap that could match this description. For each, draw the appropriate tree and the array representation.

b. For one of your answers to part (a), show what happens with 4 deleteMin operations. Clearly indicate which heap you are starting with and show the heap after each deleteMin. You can just draw the tree (not the array) after each step.
(4 Points Draw a valid AVL tree and give two keys to be inserted on the left subtree of this tree.
The second insertion should cause a violation of the height invariant at the root, fixing this violation must require a double rotation.

(5 Points) Draw all the rotations that you must perform and the final AVL tree after the following elements are inserted in the given order starting from an empty tree.
1, 10, 5, 7, 3, 13, 6, 4, 8, 9
Draw all intermediate trees. All height factors must be clearly indicated at every step.

assignments.name: Assignment 6
assignments.description:
Submission:

File must be submitted as a PDF

All drawing must be digital

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

(10 Points)

Red-Black Trees

Given the following sequence of integers, insert them one by one into an initially empty Red-Black Tree, following the standard insertion and balancing rules of a Red-Black Tree. For each insertion, you should perform any necessary rotations and recoloring to maintain the properties of the tree.

15, 10, 20, 25, 8, 12, 5

Instructions:

  1. Draw the Red-Black Tree after each insertion and any resulting rebalancing steps.
  2. Label each node with its value and color (red or black).
  3. Highlight any rotation(s) performed by marking the affected nodes and indicate the type of rotation (left or right).

(10 Points)

Following is the pseudo code of Merge Sort

MERGESORT(A, left, right)
1. if left < right then
2.     mid = (left + right) / 2
3.     MERGESORT(A, left, mid)
4.     MERGESORT(A, mid + 1, right)
5.     MERGE(A, left, mid, right)

MERGE(A, left, mid, right)
1. Create temporary arrays L[0...mid - left + 1] and R[0...right - mid]
2. Copy elements from A[left...mid] into L and from A[mid + 1...right] into R
3. i = 0, j = 0, k = left
4. while i < length(L) and j < length(R) do
5.     if L[i] <= R[j] then
6.         A[k] = L[i]
7.         i = i + 1
8.     else
9.         A[k] = R[j]
10.        j = j + 1
11.    k = k + 1
12. Copy any remaining elements of L into A
13. Copy any remaining elements of R into A

Answer the following questions:

  • What is the base case of MERGESORT, why is it necessary?
  • How does the function MERGE work?
  • In the MERGE function, why do we use temporary arrays L and R instead of directly merging into A?
  • Is Merge Sort stable or unstable? How can you tell?
  • Derive the time complexity of Mergesort for Best and Worst Case.

assignments.name: Programming Assignment 3
assignments.description:
LastName_FirstNamePrim.zip

Updated Makefile : makefile

Programming Assignment 3. : Kingdom Expansion Challenge

Objective

Help the King of Graphland connect all villages (nodes) with the minimum total cost using Prim's algorithm. Your task is to:

  • Implement the graph using an adjacency matrix.

  • Complete the logic for Prim’s algorithm using a min-heap.

  • Follow the provided file structure and instructions strictly.

Assignment Overview

  1. Files Provided:

    • main.cpp: Do not modify this file.

    • graph.h: Header file with the class interface and constants.

    • graph.cpp: Contains incomplete methods with placeholder comments. You must implement the adjacency matrix and Prim’s algorithm here.

  2. Your Tasks:

    • Implement the adjacency matrix setup in the function loadGraphFromFile (in graph.cpp).

    • Implement Prim’s algorithm using a min heap in the function primMST (in graph.cpp).

  3. Input Format (via input.txt):

    • The graph is defined in input.txt as follows:

       

       

      • First line: Number of nodes and edges.

      • Subsequent lines: Each edge in the format <u> <v> <weight>.

  4. Output Example:

     

    Minimum Spanning Tree:
    Connecting village 1 to village 3
    Connecting village 3 to village 2
    Connecting village 3 to village 4
    Connecting village 4 to village 5
    Total Cost: 9

     

Rules and Submission Requirements

File Structure for Submission: Submit the following files:

  • main.cpp (As given. It is fixed, do not modify it)

  • graph.cpp (Your implementation of adjacency matrix and Prim's algorithm)

  • graph.h (Do not modify the provided constants or class interface)

  • input.txt (Your test input graph file)

  1. Code Restrictions:

    • Do not modify main.cpp. Your submission will be tested against the original main.cpp.

    • Use the exact class and function names provided in graph.h.

    • Do not include unnecessary libraries or global variables.

  2. Execution Instructions:

    • Your program must compile and run using the provided Makefile.

    • Use the terminal (Mac/Linux) or command prompt (Windows) to run the program:

       

      make
      ./kingdom_expansion (Mac/Linux)
      kingdom_expansion.exe (Windows)

       

  3. Screenshot or Video Submission:

    • Attach a screenshot or a short video showing your program running and producing the correct output.

    • This will confirm you successfully compiled and executed your code.

  4. README is NOT required.

Grading Rubric (100 Points)

Category

Points

Graph Representation (30 Points)

- Adjacency matrix setup in loadGraphFromFile is correct

15

- Handles edge cases (e.g., missing edges, disconnected nodes)

10

- Efficient and clean implementation

5

Prim's Algorithm (50 Points)

- Finds the correct MST using min heap

20

- Handles edge cases (e.g., no MST exists)

10

- Fills mstStart and mstEnd vectors accurately

10

- Correctly calculates the total cost of MST

10

Execution and Terminal Testing (20 Points)

- Compiles without errors using the provided Makefile

10

- Successfully runs in the terminal environment

10

Total

100

Instructions to Run the Program

  1. On Mac/Linux:

    • Open a terminal and navigate to the directory containing your files.

    • Run the following command to compile the program:

       

      make

       

    • Execute the program:

       

      ./kingdom_expansion

       

    • If successful, the program will output the MST and its total cost.

  2. On Windows:

    • Open the command prompt and navigate to the directory containing your files.

    • Run the following command to compile the program:

       

      make

       

    • Execute the program:

       

      kingdom_expansion.exe

       

    • If successful, the program will output the MST and its total cost.

Hints:

  • Graph Representation:

    • Initialize the adjacency matrix with a large constant (INF) for non-connected nodes.

    • Set the diagonal of the matrix to 0 (no cost to connect a node to itself).

  • Prim’s Algorithm:

    • Start with an arbitrary node (node 1 is suggested).

    • Use the parent array to track edges and minWeight array to track the minimum cost of connecting nodes.

    • Think of MST as a tree that grows iteratively, adding the smallest possible edge at each step.

Penalties

  • Modifications to main.cpp: -30 points

  • Submission Missing Required Files: -10 points per missing file

  • Code Does Not Compile: -50 points

  • Code Does Not Run in Terminal: -50 points

syllabus:
CLASS TIMES:

Monday & Wednesday

 * 4:00 - 5:15PM @ HT183 , TA : Alex


IMPORTANT DATES:

Monday & Wednesday

 * 4:00 - 5:15PM CS210 @ HT183 , Midterm 1: Sept 30th, Midterm 2: Nov 6th, Final Exam: Monday,
   December 16th 3:30-5:30 p.m.


COURSE CATALOG DESCRIPTION:

Representations and operations on basic data structures. Arrays, linked lists, stacks, queues, and
recursion; binary search trees and balanced trees; hash tables, dynamic storage management;
introduction to graphs. An object-oriented programming language will be used.


GOALS FOR THIS COURSE:

Upon completion of this course students will be able to:

 * Analyze and measure complexities of algorithms
 * Write Generic and Reusable code in C++
 * Understand Inheritance, Interfaces, Polymorphism and Abstract Data Types in C++
 * Apply design and development principles in the construction of software systems of varying
   complexity


TEXTBOOK:

This course will primarily use ZyBooks. There will be required reading worth 5% of the final grade.
Instructions to use ZyBooks are as follows:

 * Sign in or create an account at learn.zybooks.com
 * Enter zyBook code: SDSUCS210MuralidharanFall2024
 * A subscription is $89. Students may begin subscribing on Aug 12, 2024 and the cutoff to subscribe
   is Dec 04, 2024. Subscriptions will last until Jan 01, 2025.


PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE USED:

C++ in CLion (CLion is free with your SDSU ID). Students must author original C++ code for all
projects throughout this course. Student collaboration is encouraged to discuss programming
strategies, but all work must be completed and submitted individually. Do not give access to your
code to anyone.


GRADING:

 * Written Assignments (100 Points total worth 10%)
 * ZyBooks Participation (5%)
 * 3 Programming assignments (10% each)
 * 2 Midterms (15% + 15%)
 * Final Exam (25%)


GRADE SPLIT:

 * 93% and above: A
 * 90%-92%: A–
 * 87%-89%: B+
 * 83%-86%: B
 * 80%-82%: B–
 * 77%-79%: C+
 * 72%-76%: C
 * 70%-71%: C–
 * 67%-69%: D+
 * 63%-66%: D
 * 60%-62%: D–
 * Below 60%: F


TURNING IN WORK:

Instructions on what, when, where, and how to turn in assignments will be posted on Canvas, email,
and Discord. It is the student’s responsibility to understand when and how to turn in the
assignments.


LATE COURSEWORK:

All assignments are due on the date as stated on canvas. Once the due has passed links will be
closed. Late Assignments will be marked down 25% every day of delay.

 * 1 Day Late -25%
 * 2 Days Late -50%
 * 3 Day Late -75%
 * 4Th Day - Automatic zero


EXAMS:

Exams will be closed book/closed notes. Computers/laptops and cell phones cannot be used during
exams. Once an exam starts, students cannot leave and then return to the test room. Once a student
leaves the test room, he/she may not work further on the exam. Do not seek assistance from other
students during an exam, for doing so constitutes cheating. Instead, speak with the instructor. The
date, time, and location of the midterms and final exam will be posted on Canvas.

Unexcused absences on the day of an exam will result in the student receiving a 0 on the exam. No
make-up exams will be given for unexcused absences from the exam. If the student has a prior known
conflict on the date of the exam, please submit a request to reschedule to the instructor at least 5
days prior to the exam date. Rescheduling will be at the discretion of the instructor. If approved,
the student may take the exam on an earlier date. If the student misses the exam due to an
unforeseen circumstance, email the instructor to discuss options. Absence must be documented for
rescheduling to be considered. If you need special accommodations for testing kindly contact the
Student Ability Success Center ASAP: Student Ability Success Center.


CLASSROOM ETIQUETTE:

Cell phones should be turned off or set to vibrate mode during class. If using laptops/electronic
equipment to take notes, please use it on mute. Class participation is highly encouraged; ask
questions, initiate discussions in a respectful manner.


ACADEMIC HONESTY:

The college experience is founded on the concepts of honesty and integrity. Dishonesty, cheating,
plagiarism, or knowingly furnishing false information to the college are regarded as particularly
serious offenses. Cases of dishonesty will be handled by levying certain penalties. However, in
flagrant cases, the penalty may be dismissal from the college after proper due process proceedings.


SPECIAL ACCOMMODATIONS:

If you are a student with a disability and believe you will need accommodations for this class, it
is your responsibility to contact Student Disability Services at (619) 594-6473. To avoid any delay
in the receipt of your accommodations, you should contact Student Disability Services as soon as
possible. Please note that accommodations are not retroactive, and that accommodations based upon
disability cannot be provided until you have presented your instructor with an accommodation letter
from Student Disability Services. Your cooperation is appreciated.


TA OFFICE HOURS:

Alex 

Monday - 4pm - 6pm (In Person - Location will be updated shortly)
Wednesday/Friday 4pm-7pm Zoom - https://SDSU.zoom.us/j/4480082162

announcements.title: Qualtrics Survey
announcements.message:
Dear Students,

 

As part of our ongoing efforts to improve the learning experience in the CS 210 Data Structures course, we are conducting a
research study to better understand how different teaching approaches impact student engagement, learning, and overall course
satisfaction. Your participation in this study is entirely voluntary, but it plays a crucial role in helping us enhance the
educational environment for current and future students.

 

What Participation Involves:

 

Surveys and Feedback Forms: Throughout the semester, you will be asked to complete a series of surveys and a feedback form. These
include a pre-course survey, a post-course survey, and a feedback form. These surveys are designed to gather your thoughts and
experiences related to the course.

 

Confidentiality and Anonymity: All responses will be kept strictly confidential. The data collected will be anonymized and used in
a summarized form to ensure that your identity is protected.

 

Voluntary Participation:

 

While participation in these surveys and feedback forms is a part of the course, if you choose not to participate in the research
aspect, you do not have to fill out the consent form. You will still complete the surveys and forms as part of the course, but
your data will not be included in the study. If you opt out, please provide your name on each survey so that your responses can be
excluded from the research data.

 

Your Contribution:

 

Impact: Your honest feedback is incredibly valuable. It will help us understand what works well in the course and what could be
improved, ultimately contributing to the development of more effective teaching strategies for this and other courses.

 

We appreciate your consideration and thank you in advance for your participation in this important study. Your input will help
shape the future of education in our department and beyond.

 

If you have any questions about the study or your participation, please feel free to contact Miranda Parker at mcparker@sdsu.edu

academic_honesty_policy:
At [College Name], generative AI and similar tools may support learning, but they must be used responsibly, transparently, and only as allowed by the course. Unless a syllabus or instructor explicitly permits AI for a task, you must assume it is not allowed. When AI use is permitted, you are required to disclose it clearly (naming the tool and date/version), describe how it was used (e.g., brainstorming, outlining, grammar only), and give proper attribution to any AI-generated language, code, images, data, or citations you include. Your submission must remain your own work: you are responsible for verifying accuracy, correcting errors and hallucinations, and meeting the assignment’s learning objectives without outsourcing the intellectual work the course intends to assess.

Certain uses are always prohibited unless explicitly authorized: generating or editing graded answers wholesale; producing code or solutions for individual (non-collaborative) assignments; fabricating sources, quotes, data, or citations; and concealing or misrepresenting AI assistance. Instructors may require drafts, version histories, or brief oral explanations to confirm authorship; automated AI detectors alone will not be used as sole evidence, but may prompt further review. Violations of this policy constitute academic misconduct and may result in penalties ranging from resubmission or reduced/zero credit to course failure and, for repeated or severe cases, institutional sanctions. When in doubt, ask your instructor before using AI. Responsible, disclosed, and limited use of AI can enhance learning; undisclosed or unauthorized use undermines it.
